classes.title: Basics of Websites
classes.subTitle: Learn how to create and host a website
classes.description: We'll learn how to create and host our very own website on a Raspberry Pi Pico W by following this tutorial: Getting started with your Raspberry Pi Pico W.
notes: A few more great Raspberry Pi Pico W tutorials on building web servers are here, here, and here (which uses the Microdot library to make things a bit easier).

For more in-depth lessons on the Raspbyerr Pi Pico W, check out Paul McWhorter on YouTube who has an entire playlist dedicated to Raspberry Pi Pico W Lessons for Absolute Beginners using this Starter Kit from Amazon.

classes.title: Build Your Website
classes.subTitle: Work together on our websites
classes.description: We'll continue to work together through the official Raspberry Pi Pico W tutorial Getting started with your Raspberry Pi Pico W. Finish up your own custom website before our next class and you'll get a chance to show it off in class!
notes: Learn Web Development is a free and very popular tutorial for learning about web development.
Programming for Absolute Beginners is a great book written by a homeschool dad for anyone interested in learning web development.

All programming, including web programming, uses basic text files to store those programs. If you're curious how raw text files work, take a look at this online hex editor that lets you see the 1s and 0s behind the text.

classes.title: Share Your Work
classes.subTitle: Show off what you've been doing
classes.description: You will get a chance to share the project(s) you've been working on. These could be projects we've worked on together in class or projects you've been working on for homework.

classes.title: Basics of Networks
classes.subTitle: How the Internet Works
classes.description:
We'll look at a brief history of the internet and a quick explanation of how the internet works. We'll then use Wireshark to actually inspect some network traffic and we'll use Fiddler to get a higher-level view of that same network traffic.

We'll also look at network traffic using our browser's Dev Tools (viewable by hitting Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + I or the F12 key).
notes: Ben Eater's Full Networking Tutorial Playlist

classes.title: Basics of Databases
classes.subTitle: Introduction to database concepts
classes.description: We will use the SQL Zoo tutorials to get hands-on practice with databases. We will look at the MySQL Online Compiler so we can write our own database online.
notes: Tony Saro builds his own database from scratch in this video.

classes.title: Wireless Networks
classes.subTitle: Exploring Software-Defined Radio Technology
classes.description:
In this class, we will delve into the fascinating world of Software-Defined Radio (SDR). SDR technology allows us to tune into various frequencies including AM/FM radio, conversations between pilots and air traffic control, CB radio used by truckers, shortwave radio, weather stations, and more. When combined with digital decoders you can also listen to police and fire radio.

We will use this cheap USB SDR Kit from the creators of the RTL-SDR.com blog to find these signals. We'll also use the SDR Sharp software to listen to the signals coming from the USB SDR kit. We'll also use WebSDR to use other peoples SDRs from around the world (see a map of these WebSDRs here).
notes: 50 Things you can do with a Software Defined Radio
Radio Reference is a website with a huge database of frequencies you can listen to with an SDR.
Broadcastify.com allows you to listen to police and fire radio online.

classes.title: Basics of Game Development
classes.subTitle: Start from Scratch
classes.description: We'll learn the basics of game design using these Scratch tutorials. (Click 'Tutorials' at the top for additional tutorials.)
notes: How Video Game Graphics Work
How Game Boy Graphics Work
A basic Game Development App on the Nintendo Switch is called Game Builder Garage. A more sophisticated Game Development App on the Nintendo Switch is called Fuze4.
Some other good game development platforms are Tynker, Stencyl, and Bloxels.

classes.title: Build Your Game
classes.subTitle: Moving from Scratch to Python
classes.description: We'll build some games using Pytch which lets us move from programming with blocks (Scratch) to programming with code (Python).

classes.title: Share Your Work
classes.subTitle: Show off what you've been doing
classes.description: You will get a chance to share the project(s) you've been working on. These could be projects we've worked on together in class or projects you've been working on for homework.

classes.title: Electronics Simulations
classes.subTitle: From Atoms to Chips
classes.description:
Electronics starts with electrons. To understand electrons, we will build an atom, see actual atoms under an electron microscope, learn about electron charges and fields, see how electrons move inside metal, build some basic circuits, and possibly dive into a 3D circuit simulator.

We may also look at some CPU simulations to get a feel for how they work. These include the 6502 Simulation (the CPU used in the original Nintendo), and the Arm1 CPU Simulation (the ARM is a type of CPU used in mobile devices), and the Scott CPU Simulation (from a great book called But How Do It Know that teaches the basic principles of computers).
notes: How Small Are Atoms?
What atoms & electrons really look like
An In-Depth 2D Circuit Simulator
Exploring the Quantum World - The Double Slit Experiment

classes.title: More Simulations & Videos
classes.subTitle: Learning About Other Technologies
classes.description:
We'll look back at any simulations or videos from last week that we weren't able to get to.

We'll also look at a few new simulations and videos that teach us about other technologies like the mechanical watch, car engines, and GPS.

classes.title: Coding in Biology
classes.subTitle: Exploring God's Creativity in the Cell
classes.description: We will look at the remarkable world of DNA & molecular machines with animations of unseen biology, a discussion about molecular machines, a look at the immune system, and we'll have a look at the molecule inside all life on earth that powers muscles and nerves called ATP.
notes: Your Unstoppable Copy Machine｜DNA Replication
Montage of DNA Animations
ATP / Electron Transport Chain (Harvard)

classes.title: Basics of Robotics
classes.subTitle: Controlling a simple robot
classes.description: We'll use the Rocksi Robot Simulator to learn how to control a robot. We'll also get some more in-depth experience programming a robot with VEXcode VR.

classes.title: Robotics in Class
classes.subTitle: Hands-On Experience in Robotics
classes.description: We will program a real robot in class.

classes.title: Recap Class
classes.subTitle: Discussing What We've Learned So Far
classes.description: We'll look back at the classes we've had this semester and talk about what we've learned. We'll also talk about what to expect next semester.

classes.title: Exploring 3D Animation
classes.subTitle: Looking at how computers model the real world
classes.description: We will explore 3D characters and animations on Mixamo, Sketchfab, and Three.js.

classes.title: Building 3D Models
classes.subTitle: Create our own 3D models
classes.description: We will use the Three.js Editor to create our own 3D models.
notes: The Three.js Manual gives some great information about how to use the Three.js editor.
Download 3D models at Sketchfab
A basic walkthrough video on Youtube showing you how to create a simple house in the Three.js editor.
Another great free 3D modeling software is Blender. PlayCanvas is also another option.

classes.title: Share Your Work
classes.subTitle: Show off what you've been doing
classes.description: You will get a chance to share the project(s) you've been working on. These could be projects we've worked on together in class or projects you've been working on for homework.

classes.title: Basics of 3D Printing
classes.subTitle: Introduction to 3D printing
classes.description: We'll use Tinkercad to learn the basics of designing objects for 3D printing.
notes: Fusion 360 is a downloadable, free, more powerful 3D design software used by a lot of 3D printers.

classes.title: Build 3D Creations
classes.subTitle: 3D printing in class
classes.description: We wil have a 3D printer in class to see how it works.

classes.title: Share Your Work
classes.subTitle: Show off what you've been doing
classes.description: You will get a chance to share the project(s) you've been working on. These could be projects we've worked on together in class or projects you've been working on for homework.

classes.title: Basics of AI
classes.subTitle: Basics of artificial intelligence
classes.description: Learn the fundamental concepts of artificial intelligence, including machine learning and neural networks. Explore Google's Teachable Machine and IBM's Machine Learning for Kids (a good basic example is under 'Project Templates' by searching 'Hand gestures').

classes.title: Using AI
classes.subTitle: Uses of Artificial Intelligence
classes.description: We'll look at some basic uses of AI including ChatGPT, Google Gemini and Claude.AI.
notes: How I Used Claude.AI to Develop A Modern Web App.
Building Game and Toy Websites with Claude.AI (Tom's Hardware)

classes.title: The Future of AI
classes.subTitle: Where is Artificial Intelligence Going
classes.description:
We'll discuss recent advancements in AI and how the technology will likely change things in the future.

We'll look at 'text to video' using Open AI's Sora, Runway ML, and Google's Veo.

In addition, we'll look at how AI can generate an entire 3D scene from a few photos.

classes.title: Working on a Team
classes.subTitle: Collaboration in tech teams
classes.description: Learn about collaboration and communication in technology teams, including tools and best practices. We'll look at specific tools used to help organize software development teams like Azure DevOps, Trello, and Jira.

classes.title: Working in the Cloud
classes.subTitle: Common tools for Cloud Computing
classes.description:
Most software built today will not be deployed directly to individual computers but will be sent to large data centers, often referred to as the cloud.

Cloud computing allows companies to run very large websites and programs without owning their own networks. We'll look at what is possible in the world of cloud computing and how to build programs in the cloud, including this very website.
notes: Most of Amazon's profits comes from their cloud computing business called Amazon Web Services (AWS).
Microsoft's cloud computing platform is called Azure and is used in a lot of larger enterprise companies.

classes.title: Starting a Career in Tech
classes.subTitle: Getting Started
classes.description: We will talk about how to start your career in technology and we'll discuss what careers or hobbies in tech that we might want to pursue in the future.

classes.title: Fall Semester Recap
classes.subTitle: Reviewing the course content from last semester
classes.description: We'll look back and what we learned last semester.

classes.title: Spring Semester Recap
classes.subTitle: Reviewing the course content from this semester
classes.description: We'll look at what we learned this semester.

classes.title: Share Your Work
classes.subTitle: Show off what you've been doing
classes.description: You will get a final chance to share what you've created in this class with the rest of the class.
